/. Resolved, That It is expedient to-procure {


cession of the Indian lands in the limits Of Georgia
| Q. RESOLVED, That, until cesson is procured

Mr.. Everett, after some remarks on the latencs!
Of the period of the session, and the unwilingnes
Of the Committee, at this moment, to engage in the
discussion, unless compelled to do so by determ


nation of others to debate the subject, made mo
ton that the report and accompanying documents
be printed.
The Chair thought some other disposition of the
report must first be made.


MIR. PouelI moved to lay the report on the table
and print it; but withdrew his motion at the re.
quest of


Mr.. Drayton, who moved to amend the report
by striking out all after the word "Report," and
inserting the following:


/. Resolved, That the State Of Georgia possess
es the right to the SOIL and the jurisdiction over the
lands within her limits, which are in the occupan-
cy of the Greek Indians.


@ Resolved, That the State Of Georgia has the
right to eM;ngush the title to the lands of the In
dians within her territory, and to cgisate for them
in all cases, subject to the right OF Congress to
/" regulate commerce with the Indian tribes"


8. Resolred, That surveying lands in the occu-
pancy of the Indians, within the limits of the State
of Georgia, and By the authority of her Legislature
is not All interference with the right OF Congress
to regulate commerce with the Indian tribes"


d. RESOLVED, That the treaty Of the Indian Springs
having been executed and ratified by the Greek
Indians, and having been executed and ratified on
the part of the United States, in the manner pre-
scribed by the Constitution, and never having been
constiutionaly repealed. all the rights which un-
der it were conveyed to the State OF Georgla, are
unimpared at this time.


5h. Resoirsa, That the President of the United
States be requested to cxtiuguish the claim which
is set up by the Creek Indians to the lands in their
occupancy, in the State Of Georgia, which were not
in the Treaty Of Washington.


MIR. Drayton accompanied the amendment with
some remarks, discaiming all wish to discuss the

on the nature Of the testimony referred to

ience objected to, and advocated the printing.

-he Committee we're unacquainted with.

Meeting in aid of the Har-Uora iSoldisrs of
76.-Mueh has been done BY our patriotic citizens
in aid Of the Greeks, who arc struggling for liberty


But have much louder call in favor Of the poor
Soldier, who aided TO establish that liberty We now
enjoy -Will it be said that an enlightened people
suffered the few, the very few old men, whose head.
are bending to the grave, 10 become the inmates oi
an aims. honse. To see the gray he AIDED soldier,
in tho presence OF magistrate, make oath oil ma
pauperism and present the schedule OF the few ar.-
ces, and swear that he is worth twenty Eve dol
lars. 1t chls the blood with horror to see the
feelings OF soldier thus degraded and this mus
be done before he can become = penaioner. He
| must also obtain certificate of hs service, which
after so great al lapse of time, many are unable to
obtain, and therefore precluded and suffered to
struggle against extreme poverty.


Citizens Of New York, who are willing to aid in
SO laudabc an actin favour of the few remaining

resolution that msorty Of the votes should be re-
quired for q choice. After two bsllotingl, no per-
son having received majority Of the votes, further
ballo,ing was suspended, and so the matter rests.

/. Resolved, That It is expedient to-procure {


cession of the Indian lands in the limits Of Georgia

Mr.. Everett, after some remarks on the latencs!
Of the period of the session, and the unwilingnes

nation of others to debate the subject, made mo

be printed.
The Chair thought some other disposition of the

MIR. PouelI moved to lay the report on the table
and print it; but withdrew his motion at the re.
quest of


Mr.. Drayton, who moved to amend the report
by striking out all after the word "Report," and
inserting the following:


/. Resolved, That the State Of Georgia possess
es the right to the SOIL and the jurisdiction over the
lands within her limits, which are in the occupan-
cy of the Greek Indians.


@ Resolved, That the State Of Georgia has the
right to eM;ngush the title to the lands of the In
dians within her territory, and to cgisate for them
in all cases, subject to the right OF Congress to
/" regulate commerce with the Indian tribes"


8. Resolred, That surveying lands in the occu-
pancy of the Indians, within the limits of the State
of Georgia, and By the authority of her Legislature
is not All interference with the right OF Congress
to regulate commerce with the Indian tribes"


d. RESOLVED, That the treaty Of the Indian Springs
having been executed and ratified by the Greek
Indians, and having been executed and ratified on
the part of the United States, in the manner pre-
scribed by the Constitution, and never having been
constiutionaly repealed. all the rights which un-
der it were conveyed to the State OF Georgla, are
unimpared at this time.


5h. Resoirsa, That the President of the United
States be requested to cxtiuguish the claim which
is set up by the Creek Indians to the lands in their
occupancy, in the State Of Georgia, which were not
in the Treaty Of Washington.


MIR. Drayton accompanied the amendment with
some remarks, discaiming all wish to discuss the
general subject but stating he had differed from all
the other members Of the Select Committee.


Mr.. Forsyth went at great length into course of
on the nature Of the testimony referred to

his remarks by moving to lay the report,

Of Mr.. Drauton, on the table and print

The question being then on the printing


Mr. Wicktits made some remarks, which, re.

out of order.


MIR. Forsyth objected to the character Of part ofl
he evidence, and opposed the motion to print.


Dir. Everett answered-denying that any mate
nal part OF the report rested the PARTICULAR evil
ience objected to, and advocated the printing.

the details Of the evidence proposed to be printed


MIR. Everett replied, and stated that there we're

-he Committee we're unacquainted with.


The debate was further prosecuted by Messrs

5000 also was moved, and 1000.

II was sih unaffected dfdence, at the commence

Mr.. .NcDabie moved the following resolution
Eesolred. That the Clerk of this House be author

and the inability of the publishers to persevere in

Articulation proportioned to its great public utility

The following resolution, laid on the table by

Resotced, That the President fthe United States

captures and condemnations under the slave trade
laws, whom this Government may desire to return
10 their respective Territories, Provinces, or Do

long.

Meeting in aid of the Har-Uora iSoldisrs of
76.-Mueh has been done BY our patriotic citizens
in aid Of the Greeks, who arc struggling for liberty


But have much louder call in favor Of the poor
Soldier, who aided TO establish that liberty We now
enjoy -Will it be said that an enlightened people
suffered the few, the very few old men, whose head.
are bending to the grave, 10 become the inmates oi
an aims. honse. To see the gray he AIDED soldier,
in tho presence OF magistrate, make oath oil ma
pauperism and present the schedule OF the few ar.-

be done before he can become = penaioner. He
| must also obtain certificate of hs service, which
after so great al lapse of time, many are unable to
obtain, and therefore precluded and suffered to
struggle against extreme poverty.


Citizens Of New York, who are willing to aid in

quired for q choice. After two bsllotingl, no per-
son having received majority Of the votes, further
ballo,ing was suspended, and so the matter rests.
